Expectation1: Ensuring financial stability for the family
Situation1: The family requires money for daily living expenses, and the parent needs to provide it
Situation2: A winter storm is slowing traffic while the passenger must catch an international flight
Story: The snow was coming down harder than I’d seen all winter, thick flakes swirling in the headlights as I gripped the steering wheel. My passenger in the back seat kept glancing at his watch, his voice tight with urgency—he had to make his flight, he said, it was international, he couldn’t miss it. I nodded, feeling the pressure mount. As a taxi driver, I was expected to get him there safely and on time, no matter the weather. But as a parent, I knew every fare mattered; my family was counting on me to bring home enough for groceries, for rent, for everything. The roads were slick, and I could barely see the lane lines, but if I canceled the ride or drove too slowly, I might lose the fare—and the tip. If I rushed, I risked an accident, and what would happen to my kids if something happened to me? My heart pounded as I weighed the risks, torn between the demands of the job and the needs of my family, the storm outside nothing compared to the one inside me.
